name: Boeing 737-900
description: The Boeing 737-900 is the longest variant of the 737 Next Generation family, stretched 2.6 meters over the 737-800. First delivered in 2001, it seats up to 220 passengers in a single-class configuration. The 737-900 was produced in limited numbers before being superseded by the more popular 737-900ER with additional exit doors and higher capacity.

zones.name: Cockpit
zones.description: The 737-900 flight deck is identical to the 737-800, featuring a modern glass cockpit with six LCD displays and CAT IIIb autoland capability.

zones.name: Forward Galley
zones.description: The forward galley located just aft of the cockpit bulkhead, serving the forward cabin passengers.

zones.name: Forward Lavatory
zones.description: A single forward lavatory located adjacent to the forward galley area.

zones.name: Forward Vestibule
zones.description: The forward entry vestibule at door 1L/1R, the primary boarding entrance.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section of the forward cabin in a 3-abreast configuration. Seats A, B, and C are positioned along the port side. The longer fuselage allows for additional rows compared to the 737-800.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Aisle
zones.description: The single aisle running through the forward cabin section of the stretched 737-900, connecting the forward vestibule to the mid cabin.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section of the forward cabin in a 3-abreast configuration. Seats D, E, and F are positioned along the starboard side with overhead bins above.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section of the mid cabin containing economy class seating in a 3-abreast configuration. Overwing emergency exits are located in this section, providing extra legroom in exit rows.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Aisle
zones.description: The single aisle running through the mid cabin section between the overwing emergency exits. The stretched fuselage provides more rows in this section compared to the 737-800.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section of the mid cabin containing economy class seating in a 3-abreast configuration. Window seats offer views of the wing, engine, and flight control surfaces.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section of the aft cabin with economy class seating. The extended fuselage provides more aft cabin rows than the 737-800. Passengers here experience slightly more engine noise.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Aisle
zones.description: The single aisle running through the aft cabin section, connecting the mid cabin to the aft vestibule. The 737-900's stretched fuselage gives about 20 more seats than the 737-800.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section of the aft cabin with economy class seating. The last few rows may have limited recline due to the rear bulkhead proximity.

zones.name: Aft Vestibule
zones.description: The aft entry vestibule at door 2L/2R for rear boarding and emergency evacuation.

zones.name: Aft Galley
zones.description: The aft galley serving the majority of economy class passengers in the extended rear cabin. Located on the starboard side aft of the vestibule.

zones.name: Aft Lavatory
zones.description: Aft lavatories located on the port side behind the last row of economy seating in the stretched fuselage.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Hold
zones.description: The forward cargo hold (compartment 1) beneath the forward cabin floor, capable of holding LD3-45 containers or bulk cargo. The stretched fuselage provides slightly more cargo volume than the 737-800.

zones.name: Aft Cargo Hold
zones.description: The aft cargo hold (compartment 2) beneath the aft cabin floor, providing additional containerized cargo capacity. The fuselage stretch adds cargo volume compared to the 737-800.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Access
zones.description: The forward cargo access shaft connecting the cabin level to the forward cargo hold below, used by ground crew for loading and maintenance personnel for accessing under-floor equipment.

zones.name: Nose
zones.description: The nose section with weather radar antenna and radome, identical to the 737-800.

zones.name: Forward Fuselage
zones.description: The forward lower fuselage containing the forward cargo hold and avionics bays.

zones.name: Mid Fuselage
zones.description: The center lower fuselage with the wing box structure and main landing gear wheel wells.

zones.name: Aft Fuselage
zones.description: The aft lower fuselage with the aft cargo hold. The fuselage stretch adds cargo volume compared to the 737-800.

zones.name: Tail
zones.description: The tail cone section with APU and empennage structures, identical to the 737-800.

zones.name: Left Wing
zones.description: The port wing, structurally identical to the 737-800 wing with the same fuel capacity and control surfaces.

zones.name: Right Wing
zones.description: The starboard wing, identical to the port wing in structure, fuel capacity, and control surface configuration.

zones.name: Left Engine
zones.description: The left CFM56-7B26 engine, identical to the 737-800 powerplant producing 27,300 lbs of thrust.

zones.name: Right Engine
zones.description: The right CFM56-7B26 engine mounted beneath the starboard wing.

zones.name: Left Main Gear
zones.description: The left main landing gear, a dual-wheel unit identical to the 737-800 configuration.

zones.name: Right Main Gear
zones.description: The right main landing gear, identical to the left main gear unit.

zones.name: Nose Gear
zones.description: The steerable nose landing gear, identical to the 737-800.

zones.name: Vertical Stabilizer
zones.description: The vertical stabilizer providing directional stability, identical to the 737-800.

zones.name: Horizontal Stabilizer
zones.description: The trimmable horizontal stabilizer with elevators for pitch control.

zones.name: APU
zones.description: The Honeywell 131-9B APU in the tail cone, providing ground power and bleed air.

components.name: Captain's Control Yoke
components.description: The captain's control column and yoke for pitch and roll inputs.
components.interactionText: Grasp the captain's yoke. Turn left or right for roll, push forward or pull back for pitch control.

components.name: First Officer's Control Yoke
components.description: The first officer's control column, mechanically linked to the captain's yoke.
components.interactionText: Grasp the first officer's yoke. Both yokes move in unison through mechanical linkage.

components.name: Throttle Quadrant
components.description: Twin thrust levers on the center pedestal controlling both CFM56-7B engines.
components.interactionText: Advance thrust levers forward for more power, pull back to reduce. Includes reverse thrust and speedbrake controls.

components.name: Rudder Pedals
components.description: Dual rudder pedal assemblies controlling the rudder and nose wheel steering.
components.interactionText: Press left pedal for left yaw, right pedal for right yaw. Toe brakes at the top of each pedal for ground braking.

components.name: Primary Flight Display (PFD)
components.description: The Primary Flight Display showing attitude, airspeed, altitude, heading, and flight director commands.
components.interactionText: View the PFD with attitude indicator, airspeed and altitude tapes, vertical speed, and flight mode annunciations.

components.name: Navigation Display (ND)
components.description: The Navigation Display showing flight plan, terrain, and weather information on a moving map.
components.interactionText: View the navigation display with route, airports, terrain, and weather overlay.

components.name: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System
components.description: Center display showing engine parameters and crew alerts for both CFM56-7B engines.
components.interactionText: Monitor engine N1, N2, EGT, fuel flow, and oil parameters. Warning and caution messages appear here.

components.name: Overhead Panel
components.description: Systems controls for electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic, pressurization, and fire protection.
components.interactionText: Scan the overhead panel systems: electrical, hydraulic, fuel, air conditioning, and pressurization controls.

components.name: Mode Control Panel (MCP)
components.description: The autopilot interface panel for setting speed, heading, altitude, and vertical speed targets.
components.interactionText: Set desired speed, heading, altitude, and vertical speed. Engage LNAV, VNAV, HDG SEL, and APP modes.

components.name: Flight Management Computer (FMC)
components.description: The FMC CDU for programming flight plans, performance data, and navigation queries.
components.interactionText: Program routes, enter performance data, and manage navigation via the FMC keypad and line-select keys.

components.name: Forward Left Entry Door (1L)
components.description: The main boarding door on the forward left fuselage, equipped with an evacuation slide.
components.interactionText: The forward entry door with armed evacuation slide. Crew must disarm before opening for normal operations.

components.name: Aft Left Entry Door (2L)
components.description: The aft left entry door for rear boarding, equipped with an evacuation slide.
components.interactionText: The aft entry door enables dual-boarding operations for faster turnaround.

components.name: Left Overwing Emergency Exit
components.description: The left overwing emergency exit hatch located over the wing.
components.interactionText: Pull the handle, remove the hatch, and step onto the wing for evacuation.

components.name: Right Overwing Emergency Exit
components.description: The right overwing emergency exit, identical to the left side.
components.interactionText: Examine the overwing exit. Passengers seated here must be capable of operating the exit.

components.name: Forward Galley Unit
components.description: The forward galley with beverage carts, coffee maker, and meal heating ovens.
components.interactionText: The forward galley contains ATLAS containers, hot water boilers, and convection ovens.

components.name: Aft Galley Unit
components.description: The main aft galley serving the extended economy cabin.
components.interactionText: The primary economy class galley with multiple beverage and meal carts.

components.name: Overhead Storage Bins
components.description: Pivot-style overhead bins running the length of the cabin on both sides.
components.interactionText: Open the bin by pressing the latch. Boeing Sky Interior bins accommodate standard roller bags.

components.name: Row 1 Passenger Seats
components.description: First row seats, typically configured as business class or premium economy with extra legroom.
components.interactionText: Sit in a row 1 seat. Examine the seat belt, tray table, reading light, and service unit with oxygen mask.

components.name: Forward Economy Seats
components.description: Economy class seating in a 3-3 configuration. The 737-900's stretched fuselage adds extra rows compared to the 737-800. Standard seat pitch is 30-31 inches with fold-down tray tables on the seatback ahead.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward economy seat. The 3-3 layout means seats A, B, C on the left and D, E, F on the right. Check the seat pocket, tray table, and overhead reading light.

components.name: Mid Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the mid cabin near the overwing emergency exits. The 737-900 features larger overwing exits than the 737-800 to meet evacuation requirements for its higher passenger capacity. Exit row seats offer extra legroom with armrest-mounted tray tables.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin seat near the overwing exits. Notice the extra legroom in exit rows. The 737-900's larger exits are clearly marked. Window passengers can see the wing, flaps, and spoilers.

components.name: Aft Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the aft cabin of the stretched 737-900. The additional fuselage length compared to the 737-800 means more rows of economy seating here. Aft seats are closer to the engines and the rear galley. The last rows may have limited recline.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin seat. You can feel the proximity to the CFM56 engines. The stretched fuselage gives the 737-900 about 20 more seats than the 737-800. The rear galley and lavatories are just behind.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Pivot-style overhead storage bins along the left side of the forward cabin, featuring the Boeing Sky Interior design with 48% more volume than earlier 737 models.
components.interactionText: Press the latch and pivot the bin down toward you. The Sky Interior bins accommodate standard roller bags placed on their sides. The bin closes with a satisfying click as the latch engages.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Pivot-style overhead storage bins along the right side of the forward cabin, matching the left side in capacity and design.
components.interactionText: Press the latch and pivot the starboard overhead bin down. These bins mirror the port side, offering the same generous Sky Interior storage volume for carry-on luggage.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the left side of the mid cabin section, located above the overwing emergency exit rows.
components.interactionText: Open the mid cabin port-side overhead bin. Near the overwing exits, these bins may be slightly smaller to accommodate emergency lighting and exit signage above.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the right side of the mid cabin, positioned above the starboard overwing exit area.
components.interactionText: Open the starboard mid cabin overhead bin. The bin latches securely to prevent opening during turbulence. Emergency exit lighting runs along the bin rail.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the left side of the aft cabin, serving the rear economy passengers in the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: Open the aft cabin port-side overhead bin. Passengers in the rear of the aircraft often find more available bin space as the aft section boards last.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the right side of the aft cabin, completing the continuous overhead storage throughout the passenger cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the starboard aft cabin overhead bin. The last few bins before the aft bulkhead are popular with passengers who board early and stow bags near their seats.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the forward cabin. The triple-pane assembly provides structural integrity, thermal insulation, and a scratch-resistant inner surface.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward left window. From here you can see the airport terminal, ground equipment, and the nose of the aircraft ahead. The tiny breather hole in the middle pane equalizes pressure between layers.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the forward cabin, offering views of the airport and ramp area during ground operations.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward right window. On the ground, you can see baggage carts, fuel trucks, and other aircraft at adjacent gates. The window shade slides up and down for light control.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the mid cabin, positioned over the wing with views of the engine, leading edge slats, and trailing edge flaps.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin left window. The wing stretches out below with the CFM56 engine visible on its pylon. Watch the slats and flaps deploy during takeoff and landing configuration changes.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the mid cabin over the starboard wing, offering symmetrical views of the wing and engine.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin right window. The starboard wing and engine are visible below. During flight, you can watch the spoilers rise on landing and the ailerons deflect in turns.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the aft cabin, offering views behind the wing trailing edge toward the tail and ground below.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin left window. Behind the wing, you can see the ground below and the horizontal stabilizer at the tail. During approach, the runway appears to slide beneath you.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the aft cabin with views of the tail section and ground below during flight.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin right window. You can see the vertical stabilizer rising above the tail and the ground stretching out behind the aircraft. The engine exhaust shimmer is sometimes visible.

components.name: Left Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats on the left side adjacent to the overwing emergency exit. These seats offer significantly more legroom than standard economy but come with the responsibility of assisting in an emergency evacuation.
components.interactionText: Sit in the left exit row seat. Notice the extra legroom ahead of you where the overwing exit hatch is located. The tray table folds out from the armrest instead of the seatback. The safety briefing card shows how to operate the exit.

components.name: Right Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats on the right side adjacent to the overwing emergency exit, matching the left side in extra legroom and evacuation responsibilities.
components.interactionText: Sit in the right exit row seat. The extra space ahead gives ample legroom. Passengers seated here must confirm they are willing and able to assist with emergency evacuation if needed.

components.name: Forward Left Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the left side of the forward cabin, offering views of the airport during ground operations and the landscape during flight.
components.interactionText: Sit in the left window seat. Lean against the fuselage wall and look out at the airport. The window shade gives you control over light and views. The seat is slightly narrower than the aisle seat due to the fuselage curvature.

components.name: Forward Right Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side of the forward cabin, positioned at seat F with direct access to the window shade and fuselage wall for leaning.
components.interactionText: Sit in the right window seat. You have a direct view outside and can rest against the cabin wall. The reading light above can be directed onto your lap without disturbing neighboring passengers.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Aisle Seat
components.description: An aisle seat on the left side of the mid cabin at seat C, offering easy access to the aisle for stretching and lavatory visits without disturbing other passengers.
components.interactionText: Sit in the left aisle seat. You can easily step into the aisle without climbing over neighbors. The armrest on the aisle side lifts up for easier entry and exit. Watch for the beverage cart coming through.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Aisle Seat
components.description: An aisle seat on the right side of the mid cabin at seat D, the mirror of seat C with identical aisle access convenience.
components.interactionText: Sit in the right aisle seat. Direct aisle access makes this a popular choice for frequent flyers. The overhead bin is easily reachable from here. Keep your elbow tucked in when the cart passes.

components.name: Last Row Left Seats
components.description: The last row of seats on the left side of the aft cabin, directly against the rear bulkhead. These seats have limited or no recline and are close to the aft galley and lavatories.
components.interactionText: Sit in the last row. The seat recline is limited by the bulkhead behind you. You can hear the galley activity and lavatory doors. On the plus side, you are first to be served meals from the aft galley.

components.name: Last Row Right Seats
components.description: The last row of seats on the right side of the aft cabin, adjacent to the rear bulkhead with limited recline. Proximity to the aft galley means quick meal service but also galley noise.
components.interactionText: Sit in the last row on the right. The seat barely reclines due to the bulkhead. Galley sounds and lavatory traffic are constant companions, but you will be among the first served during meal service.

components.name: Forward Cargo Containers
components.description: LD3-45 cargo containers stacked on loading rails in the forward cargo hold. These half-width containers are specifically designed for narrow-body aircraft like the 737, each holding up to 1,500 lbs of baggage or freight.
components.interactionText: Examine the LD3-45 containers secured on the cargo loading rails. Each aluminum container is contoured to fit the lower fuselage shape. Ground crews slide them along the powered roller system during loading.

components.name: Forward Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: A heavy-duty cargo net and barrier system in the forward cargo hold that prevents load shifting during flight. The nets are rated to withstand 9g forward loads per FAA certification requirements.
components.interactionText: Inspect the cargo restraint net stretched across the hold. The woven nylon barrier clips to floor-mounted fittings and prevents cargo from shifting during turbulence or emergency maneuvers.

components.name: Forward Cargo Door Mechanism
components.description: The powered forward cargo door on the starboard side of the fuselage. The door is electrically actuated and features multiple locking mechanisms and a pressure seal to maintain cabin pressurization.
components.interactionText: Examine the forward cargo door mechanism. The door lifts upward on powered actuators. Multiple lock pins engage sequentially, and a pressure seal inflates around the door frame to maintain pressurization.

components.name: Aft Cargo Containers
components.description: LD3-45 cargo containers and bulk-loaded baggage in the aft cargo hold. This compartment typically carries checked passenger baggage and additional freight.
components.interactionText: Examine the aft cargo containers on their loading rails. Passenger checked bags are typically loaded here, with fragile and priority items placed last for first off-loading at the destination.

components.name: Aft Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: Cargo barrier and restraint netting in the aft cargo hold, securing loose baggage and preventing load shift that could affect the aircraft's center of gravity.
components.interactionText: Inspect the aft cargo net. Proper cargo restraint is critical for maintaining the aircraft's weight and balance within safe limits throughout the flight.

components.name: Aft Cargo Door Mechanism
components.description: The powered aft cargo door on the starboard side, providing access to the aft cargo hold. Features the same multi-lock and pressure seal design as the forward cargo door.
components.interactionText: Examine the aft cargo door. Like the forward door, it lifts upward with powered actuators. Safety interlocks prevent the door from being opened when the cabin is pressurized.

components.name: Left CFM56-7B26 Engine
components.description: The left CFM56-7B26 turbofan producing 27,300 lbs of thrust with the distinctive flat-bottomed nacelle.
components.interactionText: Examine the CFM56-7B engine with its 61-inch fan and 5.1:1 bypass ratio.

components.name: Right CFM56-7B26 Engine
components.description: The right CFM56-7B26 turbofan, identical to the left engine.
components.interactionText: Examine the right engine with cascade-type thrust reverser system.

components.name: Nose Landing Gear Assembly
components.description: The steerable nose gear with dual wheels, retracting forward into the nose wheel well.
components.interactionText: Inspect the nose gear with oleo-pneumatic shock absorbers and shimmy damper.

components.name: Left Main Landing Gear
components.description: The left main gear with dual wheels and carbon brakes, retracting inward.
components.interactionText: Inspect the main gear with carbon brakes rated for maximum landing weight.

components.name: Right Main Landing Gear
components.description: The right main gear, identical to the left unit.
components.interactionText: Inspect the right main gear with anti-skid braking system.

components.name: Left Aileron
components.description: The left outboard aileron on the trailing edge of the port wing.
components.interactionText: The left aileron deflects upward when turning left, reducing lift on this wing.

components.name: Right Aileron
components.description: The right outboard aileron, working in opposition to the left aileron for roll control.
components.interactionText: The right aileron works opposite to the left aileron for differential lift.

components.name: Left Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Double-slotted trailing edge flaps on the left wing for increased lift at low speeds.
components.interactionText: The Fowler flaps extend rearward and downward in settings from 1 to 40 degrees.

components.name: Right Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Double-slotted trailing edge flaps on the right wing, deploying symmetrically with the left.
components.interactionText: Watch the flaps extend on rails for additional lift during takeoff and landing.

components.name: Left Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Leading edge slats on the left wing that extend to delay stall.
components.interactionText: The slats deploy with flap extension, delaying stall to higher angles of attack.

components.name: Right Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Leading edge slats on the right wing, operating symmetrically with the left.
components.interactionText: Right leading edge slats deploy in concert with the left side.

components.name: Elevator
components.description: Elevators on the horizontal stabilizer for pitch control.
components.interactionText: The elevators deflect upward when the yoke is pulled back, pitching the nose up.

components.name: Rudder
components.description: The rudder on the vertical stabilizer for yaw control, with dual-actuator safety system.
components.interactionText: The rudder deflects to yaw the aircraft, with yaw damper for Dutch roll suppression.

components.name: Wing Spoilers / Speed Brakes
components.description: Spoiler panels on both wings for speed brakes, ground spoilers, and roll assist.
components.interactionText: Spoilers deploy symmetrically as speed brakes or asymmetrically to assist roll control.

components.name: Weather Radar Antenna
components.description: The weather radar housed in the nose radome for detecting storms ahead of the aircraft.
components.interactionText: The MultiScan radar detects weather at multiple altitudes simultaneously.

components.name: APU Exhaust
components.description: The Honeywell 131-9B APU exhaust at the tail cone.
components.interactionText: The APU provides ground power and bleed air for engine starting.

controlSurfaces.name: Ailerons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke turned left: left aileron up, right aileron down. Yoke turned right: opposite deflection.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Differential lift between wings rolls the aircraft in the direction of yoke input, initiating a banked turn.

controlSurfaces.name: Elevator
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke pulled back: elevators deflect upward. Yoke pushed forward: elevators deflect downward.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Upward elevator creates downward tail force, pitching the nose up for climb. Forward yoke pitches nose down for descent.

controlSurfaces.name: Rudder
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Left rudder pedal pressed: rudder deflects left. Right pedal: rudder deflects right.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Rudder deflection yaws the aircraft nose in the direction of pedal input. Used for coordinated turns and crosswind correction.

controlSurfaces.name: Trailing Edge Flaps
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flap lever moved through detents 1, 2, 5, 10, 15, 25, 30, 40. Flaps extend progressively.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Extending flaps increases lift and drag, reducing takeoff and landing speeds. Higher settings enable steeper approaches.

controlSurfaces.name: Leading Edge Slats
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Slats extend automatically with flap selection, deploying forward and down from the leading edge.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Extended slats delay stall by energizing airflow over the wing, allowing safe flight at lower speeds.

controlSurfaces.name: Spoilers / Speed Brakes
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Speed brake lever raised: symmetric deployment. During roll: asymmetric deployment assists ailerons.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Symmetric deployment increases drag and reduces lift for descent. Ground deployment destroys lift for maximum braking.
